docs.snippet: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 8--Brazilians who have been living abroad during the 15 years of military rule here have been flocking home this week to delirious airport reunions in the wake of a Government amnesty.
docs.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 8--Brazilians who have been living abroad during the 15 years of military rule here have been flocking home this week to delirious airport reunions in the wake of a Government amnesty.
docs.abstract: Article on anticipated return of 5,000 Brazilian exiles as result of amnesty law signed by Pres most notable returnee is former Governor Leonel Brizola; others who have returned include Cid Queiroz Benjamin, who was implicated in '69 kidnapping of US Amb Charles Elbrick; among former political leaders who are being awaited are Luis Carlos Prestes, Francisco Juliao and Miguel Arraes; amnesty program is part of new liberalization process (M)

headline.main: EXILED POLITICIANS RETURNING TO BRAZIL; 5,000 Are Expected to Flock Back in Amnesty Declared as Part of Liberalization Process

byline.original: By WARREN HOGE Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 19  Though opposition leaders assert that Uruguay is still a police state, the military regime has reined in the more violent excesses of its security system and won a partial lifting of a ban on military and economic...
docs.lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 19 Though opposition leaders assert that Uruguay is still a police state, the military regime has reined in the more violent excesses of its security system and won a partial lifting of a ban on military and economic assistance that was imposed by the United States in 1976.
docs.abstract: Military regime in Uruguay has reined in more violent excesses of its security system and won partial lifting of ban on military and economic assistance that was imposed by US in '76 despite assertions by opposition leaders that nation is still a police state; official figures show number of political prisoners has declined from a high of 6,000 five years ago to 1,600; complete repression of political dissent and freedom of information continues, although Pres Aparicio Mendez Government is no longer faced with insurgency; intelligence services have huge computerized central file that keeps track of all people with any past political activity; opposition leaders say situation shows how military regime can improve its image by restraining most violent elements of its security system while still repressing dissent; tour of 2 maximum security prisons by members of diplomatic corps and meeting with imprisoned dissident Jose Luis Massera, who is expected to be freed, discussed; Gen Luis Queirolo, army commander, comments; liberalization of economic system noted (M)

headline.main: Uruguay Eases Its Iron Control But Bars Dissent; A Computer Keeps Check

byline.original: By JUAN de ONIS Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 28--The Carter Administration, concerned over thee presence of Soviet troops in Cuba, is consulting with Latin American governments on the creation of a regional military peacekeeping force, according to diplomatic sources.

docs.snippet: If you'd love to own one of those Perry Ellis rainbow-hued cardigans or a Joan Vass angora pullover but can't see spending close to $200 for one, knit it yourself. That's what hundreds of fashion-conscious women are starting to do.
